document.docAuthor: MASNER, LUBOMÍR & GARCÍA R, JOSÉ LUIS
document.docOrigin: Bulletin of the American Museum of Natural History 2002 (268)
document.masterDocTitle: The Genera Of Diapriinae (Hymenoptera: Diapriidae) In The New World

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The Genera Of Diapriinae (Hymenoptera: Diapriidae) In The New World
Bulletin of the American Museum of Natural History

subSubSection.paragraph:
RECOGNITION AND RELATIONSHIPS: Among the Neotropical genera with 11­segmented female antenna
Xanthopria
is recognized by two apomorphies: the deep cleft between clypeus and mandibles and the absence of marginal cilia in forewing. The intense sculpture on head and mesosoma also appears diagnostic for the genus. Brues (1915) described two species,
X. opaca
( type species) and
X. nitida
; after examination of the types (MCZC) we decided to transfer
X. nitida
to
Acanthopria
(new combination).
Xanthopria
is interpreted as specialized derivative of
Acanthopria
.

DISTRIBUTION: We examined two specimens of
X. opaca
, the holotype , and a female (CNCI), both from Brazil .
BIOLOGY: Host and habits unknown, but possible association with ants is highly probable.
